title: Support JSON files as Yjs map/array types in directory sync
description:
Summary: Allow synced JSON files to be stored as Yjs map/array types (not plain text) so JSON structure is preserved in CRDT.

Files to modify:
- src/document.rs (content type handling / default doc type)
- src/diff.rs (JSON diff generation if needed)
- src/bin/sync.rs (JSON file handling, initial sync)
- src/sync/content_type.rs (content type mapping, potentially new metadata)
- docs/FILESYSTEM.md (clarify JSON type behavior)
- docs/WIRING_DIAGRAM_FILES.md (if wiring files need special handling)

Implementation steps:
1. Identify how JSON documents are represented in yrs (map/array) vs text and how current commits are applied.
2. Decide on encoding for JSON files in sync (map vs array based on top-level JSON).
3. Update sync upload/replace logic to send JSON updates rather than text edits for JSON files.
4. Ensure server-side content retrieval returns serialized JSON for map/array docs.
5. Add tests/fixtures for JSON map/array round-trips through sync.

Example:
- Before: file data.json stored as plain text in Yjs text.
- After: data.json stored as Yjs map or array (based on top-level JSON), serialized to JSON text on read/write.

title: Verify diff module returns correct summary struct for replace endpoint
Represent directory trees as Yjs JSON (Y.Map) instead of text JSON
description:
Currently, the fs-root document uses TEXT content type with JSON stored as a text string. This was a workaround because the edit system (diff.rs, replay.rs) uses TEXT-based Yjs updates (Y.Text), but DocumentNode for JSON type uses Y.Map internally.

The proper solution would be to use native Yjs JSON structure (Y.Map) for directory schemas, which would enable:
- Proper CRDT merging of concurrent schema changes
- More efficient updates (only changed entries, not full document replacement)
- Better conflict resolution for concurrent file additions/deletions

title: Handle rename events so new paths get sync tasks
description:
notify reports renames as `Modify(Name)` events; the current mapping treats all `is_modify()` as `DirEvent::Modified`. The modified handler only re-pushes schema and never starts new per-file sync tasks or removes old ones, so a rename leaves the new file untracked and the old path's tasks running until restart.

Consider handling rename explicitly (or treating `Modify(Name)` as delete+create).
